questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. UserPC receives the IP address but does not register to the call manager. Which command in ip dhcp pool VLAN200_USER_VOICE resolves the issue?

comments.content: has anyone taken the exam in 2025, are these still relevant?

"the network administrator redistributes EIGRP into OSPF on R3"
you are talking about the reverse...
B isnt correct.. You can't filter LSA's within the area. If it was inbound then yes but outbound are applied to the ABR/ASBR.

All of the routers in the same OSPF area need to have the same exact LSDB. You cannot have it any other way in ospf. So this answer is wrong. You could implement a local distribute list on R4 to filter it locally from the RIB (still being in the LSDB), but I dont think this is THE BEST fix. The best fix is to maintain the backup route thru R5 and just lower the AD of external EIGRP to anything below 110.

discussion.content:
The subnet 10.1.1.1/24 is redistributed into EIGRP domain so it will have the Administrative Distance (AD) of 170. Therefore R4 also learns about this subnet advertised from R2 with the same AD of 170.In the other hand, subnet 10.1.1.0/24 is also redistributed into OSPF on R3 so R5 & R4 will learn about this subnet with AD of 110, which is better than the above AD of 170 so R4 will choose path R4 -> R5 -> R3 -> R2 -> R1.
In order to solve this problem, we can configure an outbound distribute list on R5 to prevent (filter out) this subnet from advertising to R4. Then R4 only has one way to reach R1, which is R4 -> R2 -> R1. But this method will remove the backup route so it is not the best solution.Another solution is to reduce the AD of the external EIGRP to a value smaller than 110. This method reserves the backup route in case of the main route fails

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

comments.content: Option B wouldnt work anyway since they are in same area. Every router in an OSPF area has to have the same topology so you cannot filter traffic outbound in this case.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Option A: Changing the administrative distance of the external EIGRP routes to 90 ensures these routes are preferred over OSPF routes, preventing suboptimal routing. This method directly addresses the issue by prioritizing EIGRP routes appropriately within the routing table.

Option B: Applying an outbound distribution list on R5 towards R4 in OSPF could potentially filter routes, but the option lacks clarity on how it would achieve the desired outcome. Without specific details, it's less straightforward and reliable compared to adjusting the administrative distance, which is a clear and direct solution.

Therefore, Option A is the most clear and effective approach to resolve the suboptimal path issue.

comments.content: Also to update: B doesn't work. You can only filter LSA's on area border routers, which R5 is not.

discussion.content:
A. Change the administrative distance of the external EIGRP to 90.
B. Apply the outbound distribution list on R5 toward R4 in OSPF.
C. Change the administrative distance of OSPF to 200 on R5.
D. Redistribute OSPF into EIGRP on R4.

A: If we change AD or ext-EIGRP on R4 to 90, R4 now prefers path trhough R4. --> Correct
B: This works. Now we have no backup path. And what if more prefixes are redistributed on R1?
C:Administrative Distance is locally significant on the router
D:This won't solve the problem, of OSPF having better AD (110) than external EIGRP (170)
Why not C?

Selected Answer: A
R4#trac 10.1.1.1
Type escape sequence to abort.
Tracing the route to 10.1.1.1
VRF info: (vrf in name/id, vrf out name/id)
 1 10.1.24.2 2 msec 2 msec 2 msec
 2 10.1.12.1 2 msec * 2 msec
R4#sh run | sec router eigrp
router eigrp 1
 network 10.1.24.0 0.0.0.255
 redistribute ospf 1 metric 1000000 1 255 1 1500 route-map FILTER-TAG
 distance eigrp 90 90
R4#

comments.content: It's external because it got into the EIGRP-domain through redistribute connected command.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
There are two routes on P4:
D EX (ad170) towards R2
O E2 (ad110) towards R5 (suboptimal path)

What needs to be done so that the packet goes towards R2, if a smaller administrative distance is preferable.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct,

Selected Answer: A
All of the routers in the same OSPF area need to have the same exact LSDB. You cannot have it any other way in ospf. So B is wrong. You could implement a local distribute list on R4 to filter it locally from the RIB (still being in the LSDB), but I dont think this is THE BEST fix. The best fix is to maintain the backup route thru R5 and just lower the AD of external EIGRP to anything below 110.

B is right， after “”redistributes EIGRP into OSPF on R3 “,the administrative distance of "10.1.1.0/24 network"in ospf is 110. R4 has 2 path2 to "10.1.1.0/24 network":
R4-->R2: eigrp AD 170( because it is from "redistribute connected"commad on R1)
R4-->R5: OSPF AD 110(all AD value is "110 "in ospf including redistributed)
So it will choose R5-R4
B has no effect for LSA,right?
A is right:
R4(config)#router eigrp 1 
R4(config-router)#distance eigrp 90 90
The given answer is correct

The given answer is correct
external eigrp 170 ------> 90
 ospf 110 ------> 110
the route is external eigrp because it is redistributed in.
A is correct, 10. subnet is redistributed to eigrp so its treated as external route with defaul AD of 170

comments.content: All of the routers in the same OSPF area need to have the same exact LSDB. You cannot have it any other way in ospf. So this answer is wrong. You could implement a local distribute list on R4 to filter it locally from the RIB (still being in the LSDB), but I dont think this is THE BEST fix. The best fix is to maintain the backup route thru R5 and just lower the AD of external EIGRP to anything below 110.

discussion.content: B is the correct answer. Make sure that R4 is already having the internal EIGRP route through R2. Outbound distribute-list on R5 is required to stop exporting the external routes to R4 i.e. learned from R3.

comments.content: 10.1.1.0/24 is being redistributed into EIGRP on R1 so it has AD of 170.

discussion.content: I dont think that R4 will ever take route from R5 since it should be learning internal EIGRP route for the destination route using AD value of 90 and OSPF AD value should be 110.

choices.A: Change the administrative distance of the external EIGRP to 90.
choices.C: Change the administrative distance of OSPF to 200 on R5.
choices.B: Apply the outbound distribution list on R5 toward R4 in OSPF.
choices.D: Redistribute OSPF into EIGRP on R4.

discussion.content:
A: Won't work if we add route as a deny statement in ACL as route map will skip over it, and process it in next route map statement

B:Won't work in denying tag 666 in a route-map 20 statement, as the tag is placed in the route after the entire route-map completes
D: This is what we are already doing.

C: Works, it's the only answer that actually works.

Selected Answer: C
C is corerct

removing route-map sequence 20 will ensure that everything else will be denied at the end

Selected Answer: C
Removing the route-map sequence 20 will prevent the prefix 172.16.10.0/24 from being redistributed
C is correct, Remove route-map sequence 20 and that denies redistributing any traffic that doesnt match acl 10
none of the answer have to do with the prefix 172.16.10.0/24, none of it involve deny/blocking. I'm really frustrated with the exam. good work cisco

comments.content: A question with a bad screenshot, anyway, the point is that a route map has an implicit deny. So if you are removing the route-map sequence 20, then all remaining routes are blocked. Anyway, i understand the frustration, but try and think on "the best way to solve the problem". And i understand that both questions and answers are of bad quality, that does not mean you cannot answer them. sidenote: for non-english speakers having low quality questions and answers is adding even more complexity to the exams...

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
All traffic permitted by sequence 20

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
ABC are relevant if an ACL was configured

"no ACL configured on the switch" that means the answers A,B,C irrelevant.
work smart not hard ;)

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

the "Permission denied" error typically means the TFTP server is not running or is not configured.

When I test Cisco Router and TFTPd64 by changing security as High and Read only settings in server, the error show as (Permission denied)

%Error opening tftp://10.1.1.1/test-router14-confg (Permission denied)

When I test be changing default port 69 to another, the error show as (Timed out)
%Error opening tftp://10.1.1.1/test-router14-confg (Timed out)

comments.content: I would think you are correct, if the TFTP server is not started, it will never able to open the socket itself. I would think the answer needs to be: Configure the TFTP server allow writing towards the specified directory.

Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer configured routers R1 and R2 with MP-BGP. The engineer noticed that the routers cannot exchange any IPv6 routes; however, the IPv4 neighbor relationship is working fine. Which configuration must the engineer apply to router R2 to exchange IPv6 routes?

comments.content:
same, although I think ipv6 unicast-routing is for enable routing, I don't know if it will affect route exchange. However I decided to lab and find out:
IOU1(config-router)#address-family ipv6 unicast
IOU1(config-router)#address-family ipv6 unicast
% IPv6 routing not enabled
IOU1(config-router)#

We can enable address-family ipv6 unicast without enabling ipv6 unicast routing
Correct. the ipv6 routing not enabled
